nexttext: driven by a power circuit with the voltage source $E(t)=E_m sin(2\pi ft)$, resistor $R$ and inductor $L$, described by

prevtext: driven by a power circuit with the voltage source $E(t)=E_m sin(2\pi ft)$, resistor $R$ and inductor $L$, described by

nexttext: where $g_C$ and $g_M$ are the conductances obtained from the Cassie and Mayr models, respectively, and the weighting function $0\le \sigma(i)\le 1$ is monotonically increasing when $i(t)$ increases. Also, typically $\sigma(0)=1$. The most common choice is to have $\sigma(i)=e^{-i^2/I_0^2}$ in (\ref{1}), with $I_0=const$ being the \emph{transition} current. When $i(t)$ is much smaller than $I_0$, the Mayr model is dominant in (\ref{1}), while for $i(t)$ large, the Cassie model dominates in (\ref{1}). This feature of the hybrid Cassie-Mayr model is similar to that of the Hewlett Packard (HP) memristor's model  in which the total memristance is obtained as a weighted sum of $R_{OFF}$ and $R_{ON}$ resistances \cite{HP}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="g(t)=\left[1-\sigma(i(t))\right]g_{C}(t)+\sigma(i(t))g_{M}(t)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>C</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>σ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>M</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

prevtext: where $g_C$ and $g_M$ are the conductances obtained from the Cassie and Mayr models, respectively, and the weighting function $0\le \sigma(i)\le 1$ is monotonically increasing when $i(t)$ increases. Also, typically $\sigma(0)=1$. The most common choice is to have $\sigma(i)=e^{-i^2/I_0^2}$ in (\ref{1}), with $I_0=const$ being the \emph{transition} current. When $i(t)$ is much smaller than $I_0$, the Mayr model is dominant in (\ref{1}), while for $i(t)$ large, the Cassie model dominates in (\ref{1}). This feature of the hybrid Cassie-Mayr model is similar to that of the Hewlett Packard (HP) memristor's model  in which the total memristance is obtained as a weighted sum of $R_{OFF}$ and $R_{ON}$ resistances \cite{HP}
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="R(t)=\left[1-\frac{w(t)}{D}\right]R_{OFF}(t)+\frac{w(t)}{D}R_{ON}(t)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>D</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>F</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mi>D</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mrow><mi>O</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow></math>

for some real numbers $a_k$, $b_k$, $c_k$ and $d_k$, $k=1, 2,\dots $.

The area, say $A$, enclosed by the pinched hysteresis loop $u$-$i$ over half period $t_*\le t<t_*+T/2$, $T=1/f$, equals

The area, say $A$, enclosed by the pinched hysteresis loop $u$-$i$ over half period $t_*\le t<t_*+T/2$, $T=1/f$, equals
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="A=\oint udi=\int_{t_{*}}^{t_{*}+T/2}\!\!u(di/dt)dt." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∮</mo><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mpadded width="-3.4pt"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></msubsup></mpadded><mrow><mi>u</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><mi>d</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Notice that the right-hand side of (\ref{6}) contains integrals of various products of the cosine and sine terms. The integrals are computed over half of the period $T=1/f$, that is for $t_*\le t<t_*+T/2$. Such integrals can be computed according to the well-known formulas
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\begin{array}[]{rcl}\!\!A&\!\!=&\frac{1}{L}\int_{t_{*}}^{t_{*}+T/2}\sum\limits%
_{k=1}^{\infty}\left[a_{k}cos(2\pi fkt)+b_{k}sin(2\pi fkt)\right]\times\\
&&\{\!E_{m}sin(2\pi ft)\!-\!\!\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\!\left[a_{k}cos(2\pi
fkt%
)\!+\!b_{k}sin(2\pi fkt)\right]\\
&&\hskip 42.679134pt-R\sum\limits_{k=1}^{\infty}\!\left[c_{k}cos(2\pi fkt)\!+%
\!d_{k}sin(2\pi fkt)\right]\}dt.\end{array}" display="block"><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mpadded lspace="-3.4pt" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></munderover><mrow><mo>[</mo><msub><mi>a</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mi>c</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>s</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>k</mi><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>b</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mi>s</mi><mi>i</mi><mi>n</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>f</mi><mi>k</mi><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo>×</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd/><mtd/><mtd prevtext: Notice that the right-hand side of (\ref{6}) contains integrals of various products of the cosine and sine terms. The integrals are computed over half of the period $T=1/f$, that is for $t_*\le t<t_*+T/2$. Such integrals can be computed according to the well-known formulas
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\int_{t_{*}}^{t_{*}+T/2}\!\!\!\!\!p_{k}sin(2\pi fkt)\times q_{l}sin(2\pi flt)%
dt=\Bigg{\{}\!\!\begin{array}[]{lll}\frac{p_{k}q_{k}}{4f}&\!\!for&k=l\\
0&\!\!for&k\neq l\end{array}" display="block"><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="-8.5pt"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></msubsup></mpadded><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>×</mo><msub><mi>q</mi><mi>l</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="260%" minsize="260%" rspace="0pt">{</mo><mtable columnspacing="5pt" displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>p</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>q</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>f</mi></mrow></mfrac></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mpadded lspace="-3.4pt" width="-3.4pt"><mi>f</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mpadded lspace="-3.4pt" width="-3.4pt"><mi>f</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><mi>o</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi></mrow></mtd><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>≠</mo><mi>l</mi></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable><mi/></mrow></mrow></math>
